description:
Joel is a manager who is doing an activity that involves establishing and maintaining the
positive employee-employer relationships that contribute to satisfactory productivity and a
cohesive work environment. This is defined as:
explanation:
A) Employee relations is the managerial activity that involves establishing and
maintaining the positive employee-employer relationships that contribute to satisfactory
productivity, motivation, morale, and discipline, and to maintaining a positive, productive, and
cohesive work environment.

description:
________ is the activity that involves establishing and maintaining the positive employee-
employer relationship.
explanation:
B) Employee relations is the activity that involves establishing and maintaining the
positive employee-employer relationship that contributes to satisfactory productivity, motivation,
morale, discipline and to maintaining a positive, productive and cohesive work environment.

description: Unfair treatment of employees in the workplace causes all the following EXCEPT ________.
explanation:
C) Employees who suffered unfair treatment at work know it is demoralizing.
Unfair treatment reduces morale, increases stress, and has negative effects on performance.

description: Which of the following is NOT an effect of an abusive supervisor?

options.A: more likely to stay with the company

explanation:
A) Employees of abusive supervisors are more likely to quit and to report lower
job and life satisfaction and higher stress.

description:
According to surveys, at work, fair treatment reflects concrete actions such as, "Employees are
treated with respect and ________."
explanation:
B) One survey found 45% of employees said they had worked for abusive bosses.
At work, fair treatment reflects concrete actions such as "Employees are treated with respect"
and "Employees are treated fairly."

description: What are the two main components of organizational justice?
explanation:
B) Experts generally define organizational justice in terms of at least two
components—distributive justice and procedural justice. Distributive justice refers to the fairness
of outcomes. Procedural justice refers to the fairness of the process.

description:
Which component of organizational justice refers to the fairness and justice of a decision's
result?
explanation: A) Distributive justice refers to the fairness and justice of the outcomes.

description: The distributive justice component of organizational justice is best defined as the ________.

options.C: degree to which the decision is moral
options.D: extent to which the decision is good or bad

explanation: B) Distributive justice refers to the fairness and justice of the outcomes.

description: Which component of organizational justice refers to the fairness of a process?
explanation: B) Procedural justice refers to the fairness of the process.

description: Which of the following best defines procedural justice?

options.B: manner in which firms conduct business
options.C: fairness of the process used to make a decision
options.D: manner in which managers treat subordinates

explanation:
C) Distributive justice refers to the fairness and justice of the outcomes. Procedural
justice refers to the fairness of the process.

description:
The company Wilson works for believes it should (and it does) channel resources toward
improving one or more segments of society other than the firm's owners or stockholders. This is
known as:
explanation:
D) Corporate social responsibility refers to the extent to which companies should
and do channel resources toward improving one or more segments of society other than the
firm's owners or stockholders.

description:
As a manager, all of the following would most likely encourage ethical behavior among
subordinates EXCEPT ________.
explanation:
D) Taking credit for others' work is one way that managers lead subordinates
towards unethical behavior. Managers need to set good examples, clarify expectations, reward
honesty, and penalize wrongdoing.

description:
Johnson & Johnson has a corporate ethics code that states "We believe our first responsibility
is to the doctors, nurses and patients, to mothers and fathers and all others who use our products
and services." What is the most likely purpose of Johnson & Johnson's ethics code?
explanation:
C) Johnson & Johnson's ethics code clarifies the firm's expectations with respect to
the values it considers critical. The firm expects its employees to follow the ethics code, but it
does not necessarily offer incentives.

description:
When a company rewards employees who behave ethically using the firm's incentive plan
and appraisal system, they are ________ to encourage ethical behavior.
explanation:
A) Provide physical support. The physical manifestations of the manager's
values—the incentives, appraisal criteria, and disciplinary procedures he or she uses, for
instance—send strong signals regarding what employees should and should not do.

description:
According to surveys, which of the following is the primary cause of ethical compromises in
the workplace?
explanation:
B) One study asked employees to list their reasons for taking unethical actions at
work. For most of these employees, "meeting schedule pressures," "meeting overly aggressive
financial or business objectives" and "helping the company survive" were the three top causes.
"Advancing my own career or financial interests" ranked about last.

description:
A(n) ________ is a type of formal problem-solving team, usually composed of 6 to 12
specially trained employees who meet weekly to solve problems affecting their work area.
explanation:
D) A quality circle is a type of formal problem-solving team, usually composed of
6 to 12 specially trained employees who meet weekly to solve problems affecting their work
area.

description: Which of the following is NOT an element of bullying?
explanation:
A) Bullying is singling out someone to harass and mistreat. Bullying involves
imbalance of power, intent to cause harm, and repetition. Submission is not an element of
bullying.

description:
What is defined as the perceptions a company's employees share about the firm's
psychological environment?
explanation:
D) Organizational climate is perceptions a company's employees share about the
firm's psychological environment.

description:
A recent survey found approximately what percentage of organizations use social media
tools to communicate with employees and to help develop a sense of community?
explanation:
C) One survey found that just over half of employers use social media tools to
communicate with employees and to help develop a sense of community.

description:
Julio is part of a team of 8 at work which runs itself with little supervision to accomplish a
specific task. This is an example of what type of team?
explanation:
B) Self-managing/self-directed work teams are a small (usually 8 to 10 members)
group of carefully selected, trained, and empowered employees who basically run themselves
with little or no outside supervision, usually for the purpose of accomplishing a specific task or
mission.

description:
The definition of a ________ is a temporary team whose members work on specific
analytical assignments, such as how to cut costs or raise productivity.
explanation:
B) Suggestion teams are temporary teams whose members work on specific
analytical assignments, such as how to cut costs or raise productivity.

description:
Semi-permanent teams that identify and research work processes and develop solutions to
work-related problems are called:
explanation:
C) Problem-solving teams are semi-permanent teams that identify and research
work processes and develop solutions to work-related problems.

description: Self-managed teams typically have how many members?
explanation: C) Self-managed teams generally have 8-10 members.

description: Which type of bullying involves hitting, punching, and shoving?
explanation:
D) Bullying can take many forms. Physical bullying involves hitting, punching,
and shoving.

description: Which type of bullying involves name-calling and teasing?
explanation:
A) Bullying can take many forms. Verbal bullying involves name-calling and
teasing.

description:
Which type of bullying involves using the Internet, mobile phones, or other digital
technologies to harm others?
explanation:
C) Bullying can take many forms. Cyber bullying involves using the Internet,
mobile phones, or other digital technologies to harm others.

description:
Which element of bullying involves the use of power to control or harm and the people being
bullied may have a hard time defending themselves?
explanation:
B) Bullying involves three things: imbalance of power, intent to cause harm, and
repetition.

description: ________ is/are actions not done by accident but with a goal to cause harm.
explanation:
C) Intent to cause harm is an element of bullying. Intent to cause harm is actions
done by the person bullying with a goal to cause harm.

description: All of the following are common elements of bullying EXCEPT ________.
explanation:
C) All types of bullying typically include an imbalance of power, an intent to cause
harm, and repetitive occurrences. Not all bullying involves verbal name-calling.

description:
Which type of bullying involves spreading rumors and purposely breaking up friendships in
the workplace?
explanation:
D) Social bullying involves spreading rumors, breaking up friendships, and leaving
people out on purpose.

description: The principles of conduct governing an individual or a group are referred to as ________.
explanation:
B) Ethics refers to "the principles of conduct governing an individual or a group;
specifically, the standards you use to decide what your conduct should be."

description:
________ means society's accepted standards of behavior and always involves basic
questions of right and wrong.
explanation:
C) Morality means society's accepted standards of behavior and always involves
basic questions of right and wrong, such as stealing, murder, and how to treat other people.

description: Ethics refers to the ________.

options.A: basic beliefs about what is right or wrong
options.B: principles of conduct governing an individual or group
options.C: standards used by the organization to decide upon proper conduct
options.D: standards of behavior accepted by society

explanation:
B) Ethics refers to "the principles of conduct governing an individual or a group,"
specifically, the standards you use to decide what your conduct should be. A normative judgment
means that something is right or wrong. Morals are society's highest accepted standards of
behavior.

description:
Which of the following guides the most serious societal behaviors such as murder, stealing,
and slander?
explanation:
D) Moral standards guide behaviors of the most serious consequence to society's
well-being, such as murder, lying, and slander. Morality means society's accepted standards of
behavior and always involves basic questions of right and wrong, such as stealing, murder, and
how to treat people.

description:
Based on research into ethical behavior in the workplace, which of the following is a true
statement?

options.A: Offering rewards for ethical behavior supports the intrinsic nature of personal ethics.
options.B: Punishing unethical behavior fails to alter the behavior of others in the workplace.
options.C: Managers significantly influence the ethical behavior of their subordinates.
options.D: Employees feel uncomfortable discussing ethics, so it should be avoided.

explanation:
C) Managers do a lot to influence ethics. According to one report, workplace
misconduct dropped dramatically when employees said their supervisors exhibited ethical
behavior. Rewarding ethical behavior can backfire, while punishing unethical behavior is
essential. Discussing ethics openly is beneficial.

description:
Which of the following terms refers to the characteristic values, traditions, and behaviors a
company's employees share?
explanation:
A) Organizational culture is the characteristic values, traditions, and behaviors a
company's employees share.

description: Which of the following best defines organizational culture?

options.A: basic beliefs about what is right or wrong within a business or corporation
options.B: characteristic values, traditions, and behaviors a firm's employees share
options.C: principles of conduct governing an individual, group, or company
options.D: standards used by an organization to determine proper conduct

explanation:
B) Organizational culture is the characteristic values, traditions, and behaviors a
company's employees share. A value is a basic belief about right and wrong or what you should
or should not do.

description: Which of the following best defines values as they relate to organizational culture?

options.B: principles of conduct governing an individual or group
options.C: basic beliefs about what is right or wrong
options.D: standards of behavior accepted by society

explanation:
C) A value is a basic belief about right and wrong or what you should or should
not do.

description:
The applicant screening process would most likely be considered unfair if an HR manager
________.
explanation:
B) The screening process should focus on job-related criteria rather than
personality issues. Two-way communication is essential to screening applicants. Applicants
should have a chance to demonstrate competency and appeal decisions. Applicants see a
selection system as fair to the extent that the employer provides useful feedback about the
employee's or candidate's own performance.

description: What is the most likely reason for more firms providing ethics training to employees?

options.A: Employees seeking professional certification are tested on ethics.
options.B: State laws require businesses to have written codes of conduct.
options.C: Businesses fear being sued by customers for ethical misconduct.
options.D: Federal laws encourage firms to comply with ethics training guidelines.

explanation:
D) For all practical purposes, ethics training is mandatory. Federal sentencing
guidelines reduced penalties for employers accused of misconduct who implemented codes of
conduct and ethics training. An amendment to those guidelines now outlines stricter ethics
training requirements.

description:
Health-Tech Materials is a firm that manufactures medical equipment purchased by hospitals
and clinics. The firm employs over 2,500 workers in its two manufacturing facilities located in
Texas and Arizona. Recently, Health-Tech dismissed a number of employees for ethics
violations ranging from improper Internet usage to stealing company funds. In addition, the firm
has been sued by two former employees for wrongful discharge. As a result, Health-Tech's top
executives are evaluating the firm's hiring process, ethics training system, reward system, and
disciplinary system to determine how to promote ethics and fair treatment.
Health-Tech's HR department has devised a brief ethics test for employees to use when
determining if their actions match Health-Tech's code of conduct. Which of the following
questions is LEAST likely to be included on the ethics test?

options.A: What Health-Tech employees will be affected by my actions?
options.B: Will my actions reflect negatively on the image of Health-Tech?
options.C: Would I perform this action if I worked for a Health-Tech competitor?
options.D: Is the action I am about to perform on behalf of Health-Tech a legal one?

explanation:
C) It is less relevant to ask if the action would be taken if the person worked for
another firm because the other firm's values and ethics are not the issue. The other questions are
relevant for an employee to ask when evaluating the ethics of a decision made on behalf of
Health-Tech.

description:
Health-Tech Materials is a firm that manufactures medical equipment purchased by hospitals
and clinics. The firm employs over 2,500 workers in its two manufacturing facilities located in
Texas and Arizona. Recently, Health-Tech dismissed a number of employees for ethics
violations ranging from improper Internet usage to stealing company funds. In addition, the firm
has been sued by two former employees for wrongful discharge. As a result, Health-Tech's top
executives are evaluating the firm's hiring process, ethics training system, reward system, and
disciplinary system to determine how to promote ethics and fair treatment.
Which of the following, if true, best supports the argument that Health-Tech should utilize online
ethics program software?

options.A:
Health-Tech executives want to quantify the types of ethical issues that are most common at
the firm in order to provide the most relevant training to employees.
options.B:
Health-Tech managers are required to monitor the computer usage of subordinates to
determine their levels of productivity.
options.C:
Health-Tech discusses its code of conduct during employee orientation and also provides new
employees with the firm's handbook.
options.D:
The Health-Tech legal department requires the firm to post its ethics code and hiring
procedures on the firm's Web site to prevent legal problems.

explanation:
A) Online ethics program software enables firms to keep track of how well a firm
and its employees are doing in terms of maintaining ethical standards. Such software would
allow managers at Health-Tech to measure what ethical issues are most common in order to
determine the most relevant training.

description: Which of the following is NOT one of the four types of privacy violations upheld by courts?
explanation:
B) The four main types of employee privacy violations upheld by courts are
intrusion, publication of private matters, disclosure of medical records, and appropriation of an
employee's name or likeness for commercial purposes. Drug testing employees is legal.

description: Which of the following involves using fingerprints or iris scans to identify employees?
explanation:
D) Biometrics involves the use of physical traits such as fingerprints or iris scans
for identification. With fingerprint technology, the user passes his or her fingertip over an optical
reader, or presses it onto a computer chip.

description:
The business purpose exception to the Electronic Communications Privacy Act permits
________.

options.A:
employees to access private employer documents if they have reason to suspect unethical
behavior by company agents
options.B:
employers to monitor communications if they can show a legitimate business reason for doing
so
options.C: employers to listen to personal employee phone calls if the calls are made on employer time
options.D: employees to conduct personal business during work hours if they can show it is necessary

explanation:
B) The ECPA is a federal law intended to help restrict interception and monitoring
of oral and wire communications. It contains two exceptions. The "business purpose exception"
permits employers to monitor communications if they can show a legitimate business reason for
doing so. The second, "consent exception," lets employers monitor communications if they have
their employees' consent to do so.

description: The consent exception to the Electronic Communications Privacy Act permits ________.

options.A:
employees to access private employer documents if they have reason to suspect unethical
behavior by company agents
options.B:
employers to monitor employee communications if the employees have given informed
consent
options.C:
employers to monitor communications if they can show a legitimate business reason for doing
so
options.D: employers to listen to personal employee phone calls if the calls are made on employer time

explanation:
B) The ECPA is a federal law intended to help restrict interception and monitoring
of oral and wire communications. It contains two exceptions. The "business purpose exception"
permits employers to monitor communications if they can show a legitimate business reason for
doing so. The second, "consent exception," lets employers monitor communications if they have
their employees' consent to do so.

description:
According to one study, what percentage of HR professionals have observed misconduct at
work?
explanation:
C) A survey found 54% of human resource professionals surveyed had observed
misconduct ranging from violations of Title VII to violations of the Occupational Safety and
Health Act.

description:
A review of 30 years of ethics research concluded that there are three major factors that
combine to determine the ethical choices we make. Which of the following is NOT one of them?
explanation:
D) One review of over 30 years of ethics research concluded that three factors
combine to determine the ethical choices we make. The authors suggested three categories: Bad
Apples, Bad Cases, and Bad Barrels.

description:
In the model of 3 factors that combine to determine ethical choices, which factor involves
company environments that foster unethical choices?
explanation:
C) "Bad barrels" are company environments that foster or condone unethical
choices.

description: ________ refer to people who are inclined to make unethical choices.
explanation:
C) A recent review of over 30 years of ethics research concluded that three factors
determine the ethical choices we make. The authors titled the paper "Bad Apples, Bad Cases,
Bad Barrels." People who are inclined to make unethical choices were known as "Bad Apples."

description:
Researchers surveyed CEOs to study the CEOs' intentions to engage in two questionable
practices: soliciting a competitor's technological secrets, and making illegal payments to foreign
officials. What did they find most strongly affected such decisions?
explanation:
B) The researchers concluded that the CEOs' personal predispositions more
strongly affected their decisions than did outside pressures or characteristics of their firms. The
most principled people, with the highest level of "cognitive moral development," think through
the implications of their decisions and apply ethical principles.

description: When examining ethical situations, what kind of ethical dilemmas prompt more bad choices?
explanation:
B) The researchers found that "smaller" ethical dilemmas prompt more bad
choices. People seemed more likely to "do the wrong thing" in "less serious" situations, in other
words.

description: What kind of company cultures tend to lead to more unethical choices?
explanation:
A) Companies that promoted an "everyone for him- or herself" culture were more
likely to suffer more unethical choices.

description:
Carlos, a marketing manager at Devon Consulting, is attending an ethics training program at
his workplace. During the training, Carlos is LEAST likely to learn how to ________.

options.D: use codes of conduct to resolve problems

explanation:
B) Ethics training usually involves showing employees how to recognize ethical
dilemmas, how to use codes of conduct to resolve problems, and how to use personnel activities
like disciplinary practices in ethical ways. Practicing employee dismissals is unlikely to occur
during an ethics training course.

description: All of the following would most likely be addressed in an ethics audit EXCEPT ________.
explanation:
C) Ethics audits typically address topics like conflicts of interest, giving and
receiving gifts, employee discrimination, and access to company information. It is less likely that
usage of the company's intranet would be reviewed.

description: What is the main purpose of the Electronic Communications Privacy Act (ECPA)?

options.A: help restrict interception and monitoring of oral and wire communications
options.B: allow organization to monitor employees with no restrictions
options.C: support ethical worker actions in organizations

explanation:
A) The ECPA is a federal law intended to help restrict interception and monitoring
of oral and wire communications. So its main purpose is to restrict such monitoring, although it
does contain two exceptions that are used by organizations.

description:
Which of the following is NOT a major way HR managers can create more ethical
organizational environments?
explanation:
C) To help create ethical organizational environments, organizations should
actually encourage whistleblowers.

description:
Health-Tech Materials is a firm that manufactures medical equipment purchased by hospitals
and clinics. The firm employs over 2,500 workers in its two manufacturing facilities located in
Texas and Arizona. Recently, Health-Tech dismissed a number of employees for ethics
violations ranging from improper Internet usage to stealing company funds. In addition, the firm
has been sued by two former employees for wrongful discharge. As a result, Health-Tech's top
executives are evaluating the firm's hiring process, ethics training system, reward system, and
disciplinary system to determine how to promote ethics and fair treatment.
Which of the following best supports the argument that Health-Tech should make significant
changes to its disciplinary process?

options.A:
According to surveys, Health-Tech employees feel that managers do not listen to their
concerns or take their opinions seriously.
options.B:
Health-Tech requires employees to receive annual ethics training to ensure that they
understand the firm's latest policies.
options.C:
Health-Tech's main competitor uses fictional scenarios to test applicants' morality and has
fewer ethics problems than Health-Tech.
options.D:
Historically, arbitrators have overturned the dismissal decisions of Health-Tech's managers
because of unclear company rules.

explanation:
D) Arbitrators are more likely to overturn employers' decisions when the employer
fails to have clear rules and regulations. Inattentive managers, ethics training, and competitor's
actions are less relevant.

description:
Which of the following is the primary element of properly developed disciplinary
procedures?
explanation:
B) Proper disciplinary procedures require employers to clearly specify rules and
expectations of behavior, otherwise employees do not know what is required of them. Severe
punishment and legal assistance may be required in some cases but not all.

description: In which organizational document are an organization's rules and regulations usually stated?
explanation:
A) Upon hiring, tell employees, preferably in writing, what is not permitted. The
employee orientation handbook usually contains the rules and regulations.

description: Which of the following terms refers to discipline without punishment?
explanation:
B) Nonpunitive discipline is discipline without punishment. It usually involves a
system of oral warnings and paid "decision-making leaves" in lieu of more traditional
punishment.

description:
Employees at R&R Carpet and Tile are allowed to take one-hour lunch breaks. Todd's
assistant, Suzanne, took a two-hour lunch break today without prior approval. Suzanne has never
broken any other rules since being employed by the company. R&R has a nonpunitive discipline
policy. Which of the following will most likely be Todd's response to Suzanne's violation?

options.A: issuing a formal written reminder to Suzanne
options.B: giving Suzanne a one-day leave with pay
options.C: telling Suzanne that she is dismissed
options.D: issuing an oral reminder to Suzanne

explanation:
D) The first step in nonpunitive discipline is issuing the employee an oral
reminder. After that, a formal written reminder, decision-making leave, and the employee's
dismissal are appropriate.

description:
Health-Tech Materials is a firm that manufactures medical equipment purchased by hospitals
and clinics. The firm employs over 2,500 workers in its two manufacturing facilities located in
Texas and Arizona. Recently, Health-Tech dismissed a number of employees for ethics
violations ranging from improper Internet usage to stealing company funds. In addition, the firm
has been sued by two former employees for wrongful discharge. As a result, Health-Tech's top
executives are evaluating the firm's hiring process, ethics training system, reward system, and
disciplinary system to determine how to promote ethics and fair treatment.
Which of the following undermines the argument that Health-Tech should shift from a traditional
discipline system to a non-punitive discipline system?

options.A:
The most common employee discipline situations at Health-Tech involve theft or physical
altercations.
options.B:
Health-Tech has already modified its hiring process to include ethics tests when screening job
applicants.
options.C:
A court ruled in a wrongful discharge case against Health-Tech that the employee handbook
served as an implied contract.
options.D:
Frequent tardiness is the primary infraction among Health-Tech employees who receive
decision-making leave.

explanation:
A) A non-punitive discipline program is not appropriate for serious issues, such as
criminal activity or fighting. In such cases, immediate dismissal is typical. Non-punitive
discipline is more appropriate for tardiness or absenteeism. Decision-making leave is one of the
steps in nonpunitive discipline.

description: The main purpose of discipline in organizations is to:

options.B: encourage employees to behave sensibly at work

explanation:
B) The purpose of discipline is to encourage employees to behave sensibly at
work.

description: From the perspective of discipline, employees behaving "sensibly" means what?
explanation:
B) The purpose of discipline is to encourage employees to behave sensibly at work
(where sensible means adhering to rules and regulations).

description:
Several researchers have found evidence for what they call the "Evil Woman Thesis," which
is:

options.A: women in leadership positions tend to see ethics in more concrete black and white terms
options.B:
men who do not advance in an organizational hierarchy are likely to blame female managers
they have had
options.C:
when a woman doesn't act the way other men and women expect she should act, people tend
to treat her more harshly than they might if a man acted unexpectedly
options.D: when a team is created, women are more likely to be the scapegoat in the case of failure

explanation:
C) What several researchers sadly call the "Evil Woman Thesis" argues that when
a woman doesn't act the way other men and women expect she should act, they tend to treat her
more harshly than they might if a man acted unexpectedly. While such a thesis might seem
preposterous, the research seems to support it.

description:
In major league baseball the first time a player tests positive for steroids they receive an 80-
game ban. The 2nd time they test positive for steroids they get a 162-game ban. A 3rd positive
test leads to a lifetime ban from major league baseball. This increasing punishment is an example
of which element of discipline?
explanation:
B) A system of progressive penalties is the second pillar of effective discipline.
The severity of the penalty usually depends on the offense and the number of times it has
occurred.

description:
Tracy is frequently absent from work and almost always late, so her manager has decided to
fire her. Which of the following grounds for dismissal will her manager most likely use?

options.D: lack of qualifications for the job

explanation:
C) Unsatisfactory performance means persistent failure to perform assigned duties
or to meet prescribed job standards. Specific grounds include excessive absenteeism, tardiness, a
persistent failure to meet normal job requirements, or an adverse attitude toward the company,
supervisor, or fellow employees.

description:
Health-Tech Materials is a firm that manufactures medical equipment purchased by
hospitals and clinics. The firm employs over 2,500 workers in its two manufacturing facilities
located in Texas and Arizona. Recently, Health-Tech dismissed a number of employees for
ethics violations ranging from improper Internet usage to stealing company funds. In addition,
the firm has been sued by two former employees for wrongful discharge. As a result, Health-
Tech's top executives are evaluating the firm's hiring process, ethics training system, reward
system, and disciplinary system to determine how to promote ethics and fair treatment.
Which of the following best supports the argument that Health-Tech should distribute an
anonymous survey to gather information about employee attitudes about management?

options.A:
Health-Tech monitors its employees' phone calls and Internet usage to protect itself from
lawsuits and ethical violations.
options.B:
Independent contractors working for Health-Tech are not allowed to work for the firm's
competitors, which angers most contractors.
options.C:
Exit interviews at Health-Tech indicate that employees feel uncomfortable about raising
ethics concerns with managers.
options.D:
Health-Tech managers have been reluctant to terminate disruptive employees for fear of
lawsuits.

explanation:
C) Anonymous employee surveys would allow employees to express their feelings
about the company and their managers. Employees who feel uncomfortable raising ethics
concerns with managers or fear retribution for doing so would benefit from a survey.

description: Which of the following is the first step in FedEx's guaranteed fair treatment program?
explanation:
B) FedEx's multistep program consists of the following three steps: 1) management
review, 2) officer complaint, and 3) executive appeals review.
